I went deer hunting around SLC-6 when they were building it. Benefits of having a father in the USAF spy satellite program since its conception (that's what killed the USAF manned "SpaceLab" spy station program because cameras were hardier and not as expensive as humans). I have a funny story about going to the Corona exhibit at the Smithsonian when it opened and some kook lipping off to my dad about the program and the way my dad shut down that wannabe. Thanks for the photo - that really brought back some great memories. Vandenberg also has a fantabulous A-frame beach break wave but I never got a chance to surf it.

The stuff that was eating the ozone were chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs). They were banned from use and the ozone holes over the poles are now closing up.

Good coverage, Tim! I watched this launch live from my apartment building rooftop in North Hills (part of Los Angeles), about 126 miles east of the launch site. No sign of the marine layer from here. The sky was perfectly clear, and I could see it the instant the rocket cleared the top of the Chatsworth Hills 10 miles to the west, like a bright orange spark racing into the sky. Of course Vandenberg is well below the horizon from here, so it was probably a minute into the burn by the time it came into view. (The hills themselves would have only delayed its appearance by a few additional seconds.)

After it came into view I tracked it through a little Orion 4.5 inch reflector at a magnification of 25x. High enough power to see it pretty well, but low enough to easily track it. Beautiful sight! The rocket went behind some nearby palm trees and was lost from view shortly after the faring halves were jettisoned. (Normally Falcon-9s go a little above those trees, but next time a Delta II launches I'll have to set up my scope in a different place on the roof. Oh wait, there won't be another Delta II launch. Darn!)

If mentioning Aerosol causing ozone depletion, it's good to specify that it was CFCs, used in refrigerants and aerosols before the 1970s, as the specific culprit.
I've seen a number of climate change deniers who cite "continued use of 'aerosol' cans" (using not CFC containing propellants), as evidence of us not having to change behavior to for disastrous effects of human behavior to fix themselves. Ignorance is dangerous, and shorthand explanations can do more harm than good when breaking through human cognitive bias.
